The authenticity of the document has been doubted ΒΥ Dr. J. B. Kan of Rotterdam, in various Eramiana published between 1877 and 1896; at first from internal evidence, but afterwards from suspicion of Memla’s character. He objects that despite the quotations from Erasmus' writings the style is not that of Erasmus; that it is not a ‘compendium totius vitae ’; and that there is inaccuracy in the facts ⁰. The letter to Goclen he regards as genuine; and he suppooed at first that Merula had been imposed upon ΒΥ some one who knew his fancy for autographa ⁷. subsequently on discovering that Merula was suspected of having forged some new fragments which appear in his edition of Ennius, he attributed the forgery to Merula himself. Dr. Kan’s arguments⁸ have been dealt with by Prof. Fruin in his Erasmiana ⁹ and by Mr. Nichols. Merula’s character¹⁰ has been vindi· cated by Prof. P. J. Blok ¹¹ and Dr. S. P. Haak ι’.

The controversy is too long to be discussed in detail here3 hut the consideratione of internal evidence, which seem to me to prove conclusively the genuineness of the compendium ¹⁸, maybe recapitulated. Mr. Nichols shows that Kan s arguments about style and incomplete· ness are just what a forger would have anticipated and endeavoured to meet. Only Erasmus could have ventured ιο write in a style so unlike his own and ιο give a part when he had promised the whole. The really decisive point is the omission of Erasmus' brother Peter, who as “Antonius ’ plays so conspicuous a part in the letter to Rome. This latter document was drawn up with great care in order to obtain from Leo x a relaxation of Erasmus’ canonical obligations, and the facts therein stated are presumably true in their entirety; the obviously false names being substituted probably at the time of publication. In this letter Peter, under the name of Antonius, is mentioned frequently. The two brothers at first unite ιο resist the attempt ιο force them into a monastery, but at length Peter gives way3 and Erasmus, contemplating his own ineffectual struggles ιο escape the monastic net, writes bitterly of the defection.
